text: PyTorch is getting JAX like code transforms: <https://twitter.com/cHHillee/status/1367621541693857794>

attachments.fallback:
<https://twitter.com/cHHillee|@cHHillee>: Since your transformation takes in Python code and outputs Python source code, they're
1. Automatically composable with each other
2. Automatically composable with anything else (like Torchscript).
3. Able to be dumped out as Python code. 

Here's an example (2/4) <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/EvrDp5TVkAAJt7z.png>
attachments.text:
Since your transformation takes in Python code and outputs Python source code, they're
1. Automatically composable with each other
2. Automatically composable with anything else (like Torchscript).
3. Able to be dumped out as Python code. 

Here's an example (2/4) <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/EvrDp5TVkAAJt7z.png>

elements.text: PyTorch is getting JAX like code transforms:

text:
TF includes dynamic graphs from Pytorch
Pytorch includes functional transforms from JAX
What next?

elements.text:
TF includes dynamic graphs from Pytorch
Pytorch includes functional transforms from JAX
What next?

text: The convergence between both frameworks was inevitable once PyTorch started eating TF's lunch for research and looking into edge/mobile deployment

elements.text: The convergence between both frameworks was inevitable once PyTorch started eating TF's lunch for research and looking into edge/mobile deployment

text: I'm not sure how I feel about the new graph framework. It looks nice, but does feel a bit "bolted on" and adds to the kitchen sink

elements.text: I'm not sure how I feel about the new graph framework. It looks nice, but does feel a bit "bolted on" and adds to the kitchen sink

text: JAX definitely has the cleanest conceptual model and least amount of API bloat. I guess we'll see if their strategy of outsourcing higher level libraries to the community pays off, or if the core library accumulates more and more orthogonal features.

elements.text: JAX definitely has the cleanest conceptual model and least amount of API bloat. I guess we'll see if their strategy of outsourcing higher level libraries to the community pays off, or if the core library accumulates more and more orthogonal features.

text: PyTorch started off small, after all. Though in fairness they never claimed to be just a library like JAX does

elements.text: PyTorch started off small, after all. Though in fairness they never claimed to be just a library like JAX does

text: I hurts how much money and effort are being put into making python fast.

elements.text: I hurts how much money and effort are being put into making python fast.

text: when like python is very unpleasant to write
